name: qslib
description: QSLib is a package for interacting with Applied Biosystems' QuantStudio qPCR machines, intended for non-qPCR uses, such as DNA computing and molecular programming systems.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/cgevans/qslib/blob/main/LICENSE.txt>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/cgevans/qslib/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md>.
report_responses_justification: There are no unfixed public bug reports except those created by the project maintainer.
test_invocation_justification: Testing via pytest.  However, some tests require setup of a connection to an actual QuantStudio server.
test_most_justification: The test suite covers a significant majority of all functionality and code.  However, some tests require a connection to an actual QuantStudio server, and cannot be run with CI.
test_policy_justification: Only one maintainer, who adds tests while adding functionality.
warnings_justification: Needs to be added to CI.  Currently dealt with manually by maintainer (flake8)
crypto_published_justification: Password exchange uses Python standard library hashing.
crypto_call_justification: Password exchange uses Python standard library hashing.
crypto_working_justification: The password security as implemented must be insecure, as the machines being communicated with are entirely insecure in their protocol.  However, the project clearly warns users of this problem, and suggests secure setups by default without passwords.
static_analysis_justification: Mypy.  Currently applied only privately; needs to be added to CI.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: The password security as implemented must be insecure, as the machines being communicated with are entirely insecure in their protocol.  However, the project clearly warns users of this problem, and suggests secure setups by default without passwords.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: All non-real-connection tests are run via CI.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
crypto_used_network_justification: There is only one network communication mechanism for QuantStudio machines, which is insecure and plaintext.  Documentation describes the preferred, tunnel and separate interface setup.
hardened_site_justification: https://github.com/cgevans/qslib
documentation_current_justification: No known defects at this time.
installation_development_quick_justifica: Pure python/pip/pytest. However, note that this DOES NOT INCLUDE tests requiring a real QuantStudio server.
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: The only cryptography used is for password communication with QuantStudio machines, which has only one possible (and insecure) mechanism, and is prominently noted as not being useful for security in QSLib.
crypto_credential_agility_justification: The only cryptography used is for password communication with QuantStudio machines, which has only one possible (and insecure) mechanism, and is prominently noted as not being useful for security in QSLib.

name: Dolibarr ERP CRM
description: Dolibarr ERP CRM is a modern software package to manage your company or foundation's activity (contacts, suppliers, invoices, orders, stocks, agenda, accounting, ...). It is open source software (written in PHP) and designed for small and medium businesses, foundations and freelancers. You can freely install, use and distribute it as a standalone application or as a web application to use it from every internet access and media.
interact_justification: Entry points are at bottom of the Home page: https://www.dolibarr.org (several links exists to point to the good information)
contribution_justification: Contribution guideline is here: https://github.com/Dolibarr/dolibarr/blob/develop/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md
contribution_requirements_justification:
The CONTRIBUTING.md mention this link hat store all our coding standard:
https://wiki.dolibarr.org/index.php?title=Developer_documentation
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/Dolibarr/dolibarr/blob/develop/COPYING>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-3.0-or-later license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: All the code and dependencies are GPL or a license compatible with GPL and approved by OSI. The GPL-3.0-or-later license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
https://wiki.dolibarr.org  
The shortcut for the user documentation is https://wiki.dolibarr.org/index.php?title=User_documentation
documentation_interface_justification:
The documentation code for core is at   https://doxygen.dolibarr.org
The documentation of interfaces API are embedded with application at url http://yourdolibarrurl/api/index.php/explorer   (the documentation is dynamically updated according to the setup of installation).
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Each version has a tag and interim version for next release is available on branch "develop" that is public too. For maintenance version, interim code can be reach by using the name of the branch (for example branch 14.0 will contains interim version for version 14.0.5 if last release was 14.0.4)
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: See our policy for version naming: https://wiki.dolibarr.org/index.php?title=FAQ_Release_process
version_tags_justification: The tag is automatically added by our script that build the release (so no way to forget it). This script is embedded into the directory dev/build/ with the sources.
release_notes_justification:
Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/Dolibarr/dolibarr/blob/develop/ChangeLog>.
The release note is also generated by the script that build the release so no way to forget a change.
release_notes_vulns_justification:
When we commit a fix, the title of fix (re-used into the changelog) mention the CVE that it fixes.
Example with this PR:  https://github.com/Dolibarr/dolibarr/pull/6830
report_process_justification:
Link with the bug tracker is provided on bottom of Home page https://www.dolibarr.org that points to this page:
https://www.dolibarr.org/bugs-manager.php
enhancement_responses_justification: Currently only 20 PR open (recently) on 14 000+ PR submitted.
report_archive_justification: The PR and discussion around them are publicly available at https://github.com/Dolibarr/dolibarr/pulls
vulnerability_report_process_justificati:
Link with process is provided on web site on the entry page for Developer documentation
https://www.dolibarr.org/developer-documentation.php
Link is link "Security information"
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: The chapter "Reporting a Vulnerability" into the file https://github.com/Dolibarr/dolibarr/blob/develop/SECURITY.md explain different way to report privately a vulnerability.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: The project leader has a look on channel for security report every 5 open days or less.
build_justification:
The tool to build package is available with sources into https://github.com/Dolibarr/dolibarr/blob/develop/build/makepack-dolibarr.pl
The README https://github.com/Dolibarr/dolibarr/blob/develop/build/README explain how to use it.
build_common_tools_justification: We are using our own script in Perl because we need to build package using different format / standard. But our command line tools then use the common tools for each target (rpm for redhat package, dpkg for Debian/ubuntu, tar for manual zip package, ...)
build_floss_tools_justification: We are using our own script in Perl because we need to build package using different format / standard. But our command line tools then use the common tools for each target (rpm for redhat package, dpkg for Debian/ubuntu, tar for manual zip package, ...)
test_justification:
The test suite is available into directory test/phpunit.
A readme is available to explain how to launch it locally.
test_invocation_justification: There is no really standard for php language to run a test suite. We are using phpunit but there is no "entry point" to launch it. So we provide a README into dir test to know how to launch it.
test_most_justification: test coverage covers mots frequently used code but few only uncommon features.
test_policy_justification: New features are mostly build with a tool called "modulebuilder" embedded with application. This tool automatically generated the tests on it. So it is an automatic policy however, there is no document that describe this (so i will se "Unmet" for the point "It is SUGGESTED that this policy be documented"...
tests_are_added_justification: The tests are embedded with the sources of application and they are included into the same PR than the feature. No documentation exists to ask this way of working but it is the common way it works like this.
tests_documented_added_justification: New features are mostly build with a tool called "modulebuilder" embedded with application. This tool automatically generated the tests on it. So it is an automatic policy however, there is no document that describe this. So i set this point "Unmet"
warnings_justification: We are using a separate linter tool. This tool has be developed as a command line tool bu ourself so we can implement more powerful rules that generic tool for php (that we are using too). Profiles or config files for such tools are embedded with code into dev/xxx directory (where xxx is the tool)
warnings_fixed_justification: We have set all "warning" as "errors" or have disabled the one we accept into the config files that are embedded with code into dev/xxx directory (where xxx is the tool)
warnings_strict_justification: We do not accept warning. If this is something we think we can, it has been disabled by setup, if we think it is a real warning, we have set warning as "errors" that block the release.
know_secure_design_justification:
The core developers contains several developers (some of them were old hacker). See what we did for security here:
https://wiki.dolibarr.org/index.php?title=Security_information#Features
know_common_errors_justification: Core developer are helped by a security companies (Yogosha) specialized in finding security bug to be trained on technic to fix such troubles.
crypto_floss_justification: All dependencies of project are FLOSS.
crypto_working_justification: Old hash functions were replaced with password-hash several years ago.
crypto_password_storage_justification: Using password-hash for password hash, so the salt is per password.
delivery_mitm_justification: Delivery is done using git clone or packages of we are provided a signature file to check if a MITM was done. The signature file is both available with package but also online.
delivery_unsigned_justification: The signature file is available over https.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: According to yogosha (the platform we used to fix security bugs), average delay to fix vulnerability is < 7 days.
static_analysis_justification: We are using phpcs + phplint for static analysis tool
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: We have developed our own static analytics tool to look for common vulnerabilities (based on custom phpunit files)
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: It is possible to enable a mode on a develop environment to make testing and fuzzing easier (for example, option $dolibarr_authentication_mode can be set to "forceuser" so it is easy to setup tools to login to application).
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Each PR is ran throw the CTI travis to execute unit test and result is a condition to merge the PR
discussion_justification:
Discussion for dev is on github issue and PR issues.
Other kind of discussion are on forums  https://www.dolibarr.org/forums
no_leaked_credentials_justification: Some tools are checking we don't leak such credential into public repositories.
english_justification: English is official language for code comments and bug report (even if community is mostly french and spanish speaking).
hardened_site_justification: // One or more of the required security hardening headers is missing.

name: revss
description: An R package implementing Rousseeuw & Verboven (2002): Robust Estimation in Very Small Samples
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: https://github.com/aadler/revss/blob/master/DESCRIPTION + https://github.com/aadler/revss/blob/master/LICENSE
floss_license_justification: https://github.com/aadler/revss/blob/master/DESCRIPTION The BSD-2-Clause license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: https://opensource.org/licenses/BSD-2-Clause The BSD-2-Clause license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: // No appropriate folder found for documentation basics.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
warnings_strict_justification: R CMD Check/Build has its defined warning parameters it passes on compilation
static_analysis_justification: R CMD check is the language equivalent
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Uses R CMD check mechanism using win-builder and rhub, and the more restrictive --as-cran setting.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: I think the USBAN testing on Rhub covers this + Codecov
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardening_justification: The software is an add-in to the R statistical platform and does no I/O in and of itself.It gets checked with memory sanitizer flags on Rhub.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
installation_common_justification: Uses the R package building system which comes with install and uninstall.
access_continuity_justification:
As a FLOSS project for R, it is easy for anyone to fork/clone the project and assume maintenance even without access to the behind-the-scenes elements of the githup repository. CRAN has been known many times to allow new users to assume maintenance of orphaned projects. THIS github repo may be defunct, but it can be cloned, updated, and the corrections built into the package and pushed to CRAN seamlessly to the end user.

See https://cran.r-project.org/src/contrib/Orphaned/README
bus_factor_justification: As a FLOSS project for R, it is easy for anyone to fork/clone the project and assume maintenance even without access to the behind-the-scenes elements of the githup repository.
documentation_architecture_justification: It is an R package, on CRAN, which means it must conform to https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-release/R-exts.html
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: mathematical computation library, so similar to program library in details.
internationalization_justification: Software doesn't generate text intended for end-users and doesn't sort human-readable text
sites_password_security_justification: Project sites do not store passwords for this purpose. It stores SSH key but not password.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: No vulnerabilities resolved in the last 12 months
coding_standards_enforced_justification: No automatic tool to enforce the specific requirements, although many can be set as Rstudio options or through use of a linter,
build_standard_variables_justification: Built via the R CMD system which honors relevant compiler and linker (environment) variables.
build_preserve_debug_justification: Built via the R CMD system which preserves debugging information.
build_non_recursive_justification: Built via the R CMD system and doesn't use a recursive make.
build_repeatable_justification: Tested using the tinytest suite for R.
installation_standard_variables_justific: Uses the R package building system and follows its standards.
installation_development_quick_justifica: Easily installed by using R and any suite of its tools. Tested on rhub.
dependency_monitoring_justification: As it only imports base R package routines, that is handled by R Core.
interfaces_current_justification: Must use the R build system as it is an R package.
automated_integration_testing_justificat:
Uses the tinytest package and a suite of tests.
https://github.com/aadler/revss/tree/master/inst/tinytest
implement_secure_design_justification: Installation comes from CRAN or via devtools from GitHub, both of which default to https.
input_validation_justification: Software doesn't accept inputs from untrusted sources. Users will use it individually and pass the needed numbers to it for calculation.
signed_releases_justification: The actual release mechanism is not controlled by me but by CRAN as per https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=revss
